meanings.def: to win points, goals, etc. in a game or competition
examples: Fraser scored again in the second half.
score something to score a goal/try/touchdown/victory/point/run
Brazil failed to score a win, leaving their further progress in the competition in doubt.
the only man to score a hat-trick in a World Cup final
On his debut at Old Trafford he scored 154 against Australia.
He scored 20 points in 36 minutes.
He scored 30 goals in 20 games.
She scored twice in the first half.
He scored with a neat header.
She has not yet scored for her new club.
The England team failed to score against Italy on Saturday.

meanings.def: to keep a record of the points, goals, etc. won in a game or competition
examples: Who's going to score?

meanings.def: to gain marks in a test or an exam
examples: score something She scored 98 per cent in the French test.
+ adv./prep. Girls usually score highly in language exams.
Women consistently scored higher than men in this test.
Some studies show that low-income Latino adolescents tend to score low on self-esteem.

meanings.def: to give something/somebody a particular number of points
examples: The tests are scored by psychologists.
Score each criterion on a scale of 1 to 5.
a scoring system

meanings.def: to be worth a particular number of points
examples: Each correct answer will score two points.

meanings.def: to succeed; to have an advantage
examples: score (something) The army continued to score successes in the south.
Lewis scored a win with a hugely funny sketch about a car salesman.
She's scored again with her latest blockbuster.
score over something Bicycles score over other forms of transport in towns.
In the key area of negotiation, women scored highly.
The company scores highly on customer service.

meanings.def: to arrange a piece of music for one or more musical instruments or for voices
examples: be scored for something The piece is scored for violin, viola and cello.
score something The director invited him to score the movie (= write the music for it).

meanings.def: to make a cut or mark on a surface
examples: Score the card first with a knife.

meanings.def: to have sex with a new partner
examples: Did you score last night?

meanings.def: to buy or get illegal drugs
to show that you are better than somebody, especially by making clever remarks, for example in an argument
examples: He was always trying to score points off his teachers.

idioms.def: to show that you are better than somebody, especially by making clever remarks, for example in an argument
examples: He was always trying to score points off his teachers.

related: get your name on the score sheet

meanings.def: the number of points, goals, etc. scored by each player or team in a game or competition
examples: a high/low score
What's the score now?
The final score was 4–3.
I’ll keep (the) score.
A penalty in the last minute of the game levelled the score 2–2.
At half-time the score stood at 3–0.
Figo levelled the scores with a curling free kick.
The score was close in the final game.
He got around the course in 72, giving him an average score of 70.

meanings.def: the number of points somebody gets for correct answers in a test
examples: test scores
an IQ score of 120
a perfect score
to get a high/low score
This year, Jimmy's maths scores are slipping.
The mean scores are as shown in Table 1.
Other factors did not significantly impact children's scores on these tests.
Most ten-year-olds had scores ranging between 50 and 70.
She got an unusually low score for creativity.

meanings.def: a written or printed version of a piece of music showing what each instrument is to play or what each voice is to sing
examples: an orchestral score
the score of Verdi’s ‘Requiem’
There was a mistake in the piano score.
the vocal score of ‘The Magic Flute’

meanings.def: the music written for a film or play
examples: an award for best original score
The musical score is magnificent and the performances are outstanding.
The score for the movie was composed by John Williams.

meanings.def: a set or group of 20 or approximately 20
examples: Several cabs and a score of cars were parked outside.
by the score Doyle's success brought imitators by the score (= very many imitators).
the biblical age of three score years and ten (= 70)

meanings.def: very many
examples: There were scores of boxes and crates, all waiting to be checked and loaded.

meanings.def: a cut in a surface, made with a sharp tool
the real facts about the present situation
examples: What's the score?
You don't have to lie to me. I know the score.

meanings.def: to harm or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past
about that/this matter
examples: You don't have to worry on that score.

meanings.def: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past
examples: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

idioms.def: to harm or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past

examples: You don't have to worry on that score.

idioms.idiom: settle a score/accounts (with somebody) | settle an old score
idioms.def: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past
examples: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.
